headline: Texas primaries will be the first 2022 test of Trump's endorsement power
sentences:
A Times review of election data found that officials in the most populous counties have rejected roughly 30 percent of the absentee ballots they have received  more than 15,000 ballots.?
The Texas contests also present an opportunity for the liberal wing of the Democratic party to grow its ranks in Congress, Politico reports.

And whether Monica De La Cruz, who is backed by Trump as well as key members of GOP leadership despite accusations stemming from her divorce that she mistreated her stepdaughter (which she denies), can become the party's nominee in the key 15th Congressional District.

Other numbers you need to know today:
141: The number of people interviewed by the Miami Herald and El Nuevo Herald in two heavily Hispanic areas around Miami whose party affiliation was changed without their consent, the latest evidence in a growing scandal.

National Republican Senatorial Committee Chairman Rick Scott, R-Fla., another potential presidential contender, told Hillyard at CPAC that he does not plan to challenge Sen. Mitch McConnell for GOP leader.

Congressman Jake Ellzey, R-Texas, who beat the Trump-backed Susan Wright in last year's special election following the death of her husband, Rep. Ron Wright, is running with Trump's endorsement in March.

High-profile progressives and outside groups are focused on a trio of House candidates: Jessica Cisneros in the 28th District, Jasmine Crockett in the 30th District and Greg Casar in the 35th District.
But first: As the first primary state on the midterm calendar, Texas tomorrow is going to provide the first test for a number of major storylines for both parties we'll be following through November.
66 percent: The share of likely midterm voters who disapprove of President Biden's immigration policy, per a new poll by an advocacy group that used the firm founded by Biden's top pollster.
Scott isn't up for re-election in Florida this year, leading to questions about the timing of the release of this 11-point plan, including speculation that he has presidential aspirations.

Still, there are a few races we're keeping a close eye on tomorrow, including:
Whether embattled incumbent Attorney General Ken Paxton can survive a crowded primary (and avoid a runoff).
19: The percentage point edge that the Republican Party has over the Democrats with U.S. adults in the new ABC News/Washington Post poll over who's trusted more to handle the economy.

And while we're on the topic, here's an update on the census of Trump's endorsements so far this cycle:
118 endorsements (including 55 House, 15 Senate, 13 governor).
